Pose.safety: Low Impact
Pose.Name: Cat Cow Pose
Pose.Preferred: Before Meal / Empty Stomach
Pose.Diseases_Cured: Back Pain, Neck Pain, Digestive Issues, Stress

steps.step: Kneel on the floor with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Keep your back flat like a table.
Slowly drop your belly down, lift your head and tailbone up (like a cow). Breathe in deeply.
Round your spine upward, tuck your chin to chest (like a scared cat). Breathe out fully.
Move smoothly between Cow and Cat for 5-10 breaths. Go slow-no rush!
If your wrists hurt, try fists instead of flat hands.

Pose.safety: Moderate Impact
Pose.Name: Kettlebell Sumo Squat
Pose.Focused_Muscles: Quads, Glutes, Hamstrings, Inner Thighs, Core
Pose.Preferred: Before Meal / After Warm-Up
Pose.Diseases_Cured: Leg Weakness, Poor Posture, Lower Back Pain

steps.step: Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed slightly outward. Place a kettlebell between your feet (optional).
Hold the kettlebell handle with both hands, keeping your chest up and back straight.
Lower your body by bending your knees, keeping them in line with your toes. Go as low as you comfortably can.
Push through your heels to stand back up, squeezing your glutes at the top. Repeat for 10–12 reps.
If you don’t have a kettlebell, use a water bottle or just focus on the squat movement.

Pose.safety: Low Impact
Pose.Name: Kettlebell Sumo Deadlift
Pose.Focused_Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Quadriceps, Lower Back, Core
Pose.Preferred: After Warm-Up / Empty Stomach
Pose.Diseases_Cured: Lower Back Pain, Poor Posture, Weak Leg Muscles

steps.step: Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed outward at 45 degrees. Place the kettlebell centered between your feet.
Bend at hips and knees to lower down. Grab the kettlebell with both hands using an overhand grip, keeping arms straight.
Keep back straight, push through heels to stand up, lifting the kettlebell. Squeeze glutes at the top (don't lean back).
Lower back down with control by pushing hips back first, then bending knees. Repeat for 8-10 reps.
If you feel strain in your lower back, reduce weight or practice without the kettlebell first.

Pose.safety: Maintain a straight, neutral spine throughout the entire movement. Do not round your back. Initiate the movement by pushing your hips back, not by bending at the waist. Low impact, but improper form can cause lower back strain. Start with a light kettlebell or no weight to master the technique.
Pose.Name: Kettlebell Sumo Deadlift
Pose.Equipment: Kettlebell (Light to Medium Weight), Flat, Stable Surface

Focused_Muscles.Stabilizers: Lower Back (Erector Spinae), Core (Abdominals and Obliques), Trapezius

Pose.Preferred_Time: Morning or Early Evening, After a Dynamic Warm-Up. Can be performed on an empty stomach for fat-burning focus or with fuel for strength performance.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: General Lower Back Pain (non-acute), Weak Posterior Chain, Poor Posture (Anterior Pelvic Tilt), Leg Muscle Atrophy
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Osteoporosis (weight-bearing), Improves Functional Strength for Daily Activities

steps.step: Stand tall with your feet placed significantly wider than shoulder-width apart. Point your toes outward at approximately a 45-degree angle. Position the kettlebell on the floor, centered directly between your feet.

Initiate the movement by pushing your hips back and bending at your knees (not your waist). Lower your torso while keeping your chest up and back perfectly straight. Grasp the kettlebell handle with both hands using an overhand (pronated) grip. Your arms should remain long and straight.

Take a deep breath and brace your core. Drive through the middle of your entire foot (emphasis on heels) to stand up. Extend your hips and knees simultaneously. At the top of the movement, stand fully upright and squeeze your glutes tightly. Avoid leaning backward.

To lower the weight, reverse the motion precisely. Push your hips back first, then bend your knees as you lower the kettlebell back to the starting position with control. Maintain a neutral spine. Perform 8-12 repetitions for 3-4 sets.

**The single most important cue is to keep your back straight.** Imagine a rigid rod running along your spine. If you feel any strain in your lower back, immediately reduce the weight or practice the "hip hinge" motion without any weight. Look forward, not down, to help maintain spinal alignment.

Common_Mistakes.Mistake: Rounding the upper or lower back during the lift.
Leading the movement with the arms, attempting to "curl" the weight.
Letting the knees cave inward; they should track in line with your toes.
Hyperextending the back at the top of the movement.

Pose.safety: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement. Keep your knees tracking in line with your toes. Do not let your knees collapse inward. If you have knee or lower back issues, consult a professional first.
Pose.Name: Bodyweight Squat
Pose.Equipment: None (Optional: Exercise Mat, Wall for Support)
Pose.Preferred: After a brief warm-up, or any time of day after light activity. Can be performed on an empty stomach.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Leg Muscles, Poor Mobility, Sedentary Lifestyle Effects
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Osteoporosis (weight-bearing), Improves Balance and Functional Movement

steps.step: Stand with your feet shoulder-width to slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Point your toes slightly outward (about 15-30 degrees). Keep your chest up, shoulders back, and look straight ahead.

Initiate the movement by pushing your hips back as if sitting in a chair. As you lower down, bend your knees and keep your torso as upright as possible. Lower until your thighs are parallel to the floor (or as far as comfortable).
Drive through your entire foot, focusing on your heels and mid-foot, to push yourself back up to the starting position. Extend your hips and knees simultaneously, squeezing your glutes at the top.
Perform the movement with control for 10-15 repetitions per set. Aim for 2-3 sets.

A common goal is to keep your knees from going past your toes, but a more important cue is to ensure your weight is centered over your mid-foot and your chest stays up. If you struggle with balance, practice squatting to a chair or against a wall.

common_mistakes.mistake: Letting the knees cave inward during the ascent or descent.
Rounding the lower back ("butt wink") at the bottom of the squat.
Lifting the heels off the ground, shifting weight onto the toes.
Leaning the torso too far forward, putting excessive strain on the lower back.

Pose.safety: Maintain a straight line from head to heels. Do not let your hips sag or rise too high. Engage your core and glutes to protect your lower back. If you have wrist pain, perform the plank on your forearms.
Pose.Name: Forearm Plank
Pose.Preferred: Excellent morning exercise to activate the core. Perform after a light warm-up or on an empty stomach.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Lower Back Pain (non-specific), Poor Posture, Core Weakness
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Improves spinal stability, reduces risk of injury in daily activities, enhances balance.

steps.step: Lie face down on the floor. Place your forearms on the ground with your elbows directly under your shoulders. Your arms should be parallel to each other. Curl your toes under.
Tighten your abdominal muscles as if bracing for a punch. Engage your glutes (buttocks) and quadriceps (thighs). Push through your forearms and toes to lift your entire body off the ground.
Hold the position. Your body should form a straight, rigid line from your head to your heels. Look down at the floor to keep your neck in a neutral position. Breathe steadily.
Hold for 20-30 seconds as a beginner. Rest for 30 seconds. Repeat for 3-4 sets. Focus on maintaining perfect form over a longer time.

**The most common mistake is hip sagging.** To prevent this, actively squeeze your glutes and pull your belly button towards your spine. If holding becomes too difficult, lower your knees to the floor while keeping your back straight (modified plank).

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the hips to sag toward the floor, which strains the lower back.
Lifting the hips too high, turning the exercise into a "downward dog" position and reducing core engagement.
Looking up or tucking the chin, putting the neck in an awkward position.
Holding the breath instead of maintaining steady, controlled breathing.

Pose.safety: Avoid pulling on your neck with your hands. Initiate the movement from your core, not your neck or shoulders. Exhale as you crunch up to engage the core effectively. If you have neck or lower back issues, perform with caution or consult a professional.
Pose.Name: Basic Crunch

Focused_Muscles.Stabilizers: Hip Flexors, Neck (if form is incorrect)

Pose.Preferred: Can be done in the morning on an empty stomach or as part of a full workout later in the day.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Abdominal Muscles, Poor Core Stability
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Helps support the lower back, may contribute to better posture over time.

steps.step: Lie on your back on a mat. Bend your knees and place your feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. Lightly place your fingertips behind your head, without interlocking them, to support your neck. Keep your elbows wide.
Inhale deeply. As you exhale, gently engage your abdominal muscles by drawing your belly button toward your spine. Initiate the movement by lifting your head, neck, and shoulder blades off the floor.
Continue curling upward until your upper back is off the mat. Focus on squeezing your abdominal muscles at the top of the movement. Your lower back should remain in contact with the floor throughout.
Inhale as you slowly lower back down to the starting position with control. Aim for 15-20 repetitions for 2-3 sets. Quality of movement is more important than speed or quantity.

**Prevent neck strain** by keeping a tennis ball-sized space between your chin and chest. Your head should rest lightly in your hands; the work should come from your abs. Imagine bringing your rib cage toward your hips, not just lifting your shoulders.

common_mistakes.mistake: Pulling the head and neck forward with the hands, which can strain the cervical spine.
Using momentum to jerk the body up instead of a controlled, muscle-driven contraction.
Lifting the entire lower back off the floor, turning the crunch into a sit-up and engaging the hip flexors excessively.
Holding the breath; remember to exhale on the effort (as you crunch up) and inhale on the release.

Pose.safety: Maintain a strong, straight plank position throughout. Avoid letting your hips sag or rise too high. Keep movements controlled to prevent lower back strain. If you have wrist or shoulder issues, perform with caution.
Pose.Name: Mountain Climbers
Pose.Equipment: Exercise Mat (Optional, for comfort and grip)
Pose.Preferred: Excellent for morning cardio and core activation. Perform after a brief warm-up.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Sedentary Lifestyle, Poor Cardiovascular Endurance, Weak Core Stability
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Improves heart health, enhances coordination and agility, supports metabolic health.

steps.step: Start in a high plank position. Place your hands directly under your shoulders, arms straight. Your body should form a straight line from your head to your heels. Engage your core and glutes.
Keeping your torso stable and hips level, quickly draw your right knee toward your chest. Try to bring it as close to your chest or opposite elbow as possible, without rounding your upper back.
As you return your right foot to the starting plank position, simultaneously drive your left knee toward your chest. This creates a running or climbing motion in place.
Continue alternating knees in a controlled, rhythmic motion. Aim for 30-60 seconds of continuous movement, or perform 20-30 alternating reps (10-15 per side) for 2-3 sets.
**Speed is less important than form.** Focus on keeping your hips stable and low—imagine balancing a glass of water on your lower back. Start slow to master the coordination before increasing pace.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the hips to bounce up and down or sag toward the floor, which strains the lower back and reduces core engagement.
Shifting weight unevenly between hands, causing shoulder instability.
Rushing the movement with poor control, leading to sloppy form and reduced effectiveness.
Holding the breath; maintain steady, rhythmic breathing throughout the exercise.

Pose.safety: Focus on engaging the oblique muscles on the side of your torso. Avoid pulling on your neck with your hand. Move in a controlled, lateral motion rather than twisting or pulling forward. If you have neck or lower back issues, perform with caution.
Pose.Name: Side Crunch
Pose.Preferred: Suitable for morning core workouts. Can be performed on an empty stomach.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Oblique Muscles, Poor Core Stability, Lack of Torso Definition
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Improves lateral stability, supports spinal health, and may help prevent side strain during rotational movements.

steps.step: Lie on your back on a mat. Bend your knees and place your feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. Gently roll your legs to one side so both knees are resting on the floor, keeping your shoulders flat on the mat. Place your hands lightly behind your head, elbows wide.
Inhale to prepare. As you exhale, engage your oblique muscles on the side of your torso (the side your legs are leaning toward) to lift your head, neck, and shoulder blades off the floor.
Lift diagonally, aiming your top elbow toward your top hip, creating a lateral crunch. Squeeze your side abs at the top of the movement, keeping the movement focused on the side, not forward.
Inhale as you slowly lower back to the starting position with control. Complete 12-15 repetitions on one side before switching legs and arms to the opposite side. Perform 2-3 sets per side.

**Imagine lifting your rib cage toward your hip, not pulling your elbow toward your knee.** This focuses the work on the obliques. Keep your neck relaxed; your head should be supported by your hands, not pulled by them.

common_mistakes.mistake: Pulling the neck forward or sideways with the hands, causing neck strain instead of engaging the obliques.
Twisting the torso forward into a regular crunch, rather than performing a true lateral (sideways) lift.
Using momentum to jerk the upper body up, rather than a controlled muscle contraction.
Holding the breath; remember to exhale during the crunch (effort) and inhale during the release.

Pose.safety: Maintain a stable, engaged core throughout the movement to protect your lower back. Avoid rounding your spine; keep your back straight and chest lifted. Move in a controlled manner—do not use momentum to swing the weight. If you have lower back issues, perform without weight and with feet on the floor.
Pose.Name: Weighted Russian Twist
Pose.Equipment: Dumbbell, Kettlebell, Medicine Ball, or Weight Plate; Exercise Mat (Optional)
Pose.Preferred: Best performed after a warm-up. Can be done in the morning or as part of a core/strength workout later in the day.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Rotational Core Strength, Poor Spinal Mobility, Lack of Torso Stability
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Enhances functional fitness for twisting movements, improves posture, and supports lower back health by building core stability.

steps.step: Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Lean back slightly so your torso is at about a 45-degree angle to the floor, keeping your back straight (no rounding). Hold a weight with both hands close to your chest.
Brace your core by pulling your navel toward your spine. Lift your feet a few inches off the floor, balancing on your sit bones. This is the starting V-sit position.
Keeping your core tight and legs still, slowly rotate your torso to one side, bringing the weight toward the floor beside your hip. Keep your chest up and avoid hunching your shoulders.
Rotate back through the center and then to the opposite side in a controlled motion. That is one repetition. Aim for 10-15 repetitions (each side counts as one) for 2-3 sets.

**Quality over speed and weight.** Focus on the controlled twist from your torso, not your arms. If balancing with feet off the floor is too challenging, keep your heels on the ground to build strength first. Exhale as you twist to the side.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using momentum to swing the weight instead of a slow, muscle-controlled rotation.
Rounding the spine and dropping the chest, which shifts stress to the lower back.
Moving the arms independently from the torso instead of rotating the entire upper body as one unit.
Holding the breath; remember to breathe steadily, exhaling on the twist for better core engagement.

Pose.safety: Keep your lower back pressed firmly against the floor throughout the entire movement to protect your spine. Move slowly and with control to prevent momentum from compromising form. If you experience lower back discomfort, reduce the range of motion or perform without the stability ball.
Pose.Name: Stability Ball Dead Bug

Focused_Muscles.Stabilizers: Shoulders, Lower Back (to maintain neutral spine), Glutes

Pose.Preferred: Excellent for low-intensity morning core activation and spinal stability. Can be done on an empty stomach.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Lower Back Pain (due to core weakness), Poor Coordination, Lack of Core Stability
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Enhances mind-muscle connection with the deep core, improves posture, and reduces risk of back injury during daily activities.

steps.step: Lie flat on your back on a mat. Bend your knees to 90 degrees and place a stability ball between your lower legs (calves/hamstrings) and your hands. Gently squeeze the ball with both your legs and arms. Lift your knees to a tabletop position so your thighs are perpendicular to the floor.

Inhale to prepare. Exhale as you engage your core by pressing your lower back into the floor. Slowly and simultaneously extend your right arm overhead and your left leg toward the floor, keeping the ball secure with your remaining limbs.
Inhale as you slowly return your extended arm and leg to the starting tabletop position, maintaining ball control. Keep your core braced and back flat.
Repeat the movement on the opposite side, extending your left arm and right leg. Continue alternating sides in a slow, controlled manner. Aim for 8-12 repetitions per side for 2-3 sets.

**The key is to prevent your lower back from arching off the floor.** Imagine you are pressing your spine flat into the mat. Move only as far as you can while maintaining this contact. If the ball feels unstable, practice the movement without it first.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the lower back to arch off the floor, which defeats the core-stabilizing purpose of the exercise.
Moving too quickly or using momentum, which reduces core engagement and can cause loss of ball control.
Holding the breath, which reduces intra-abdominal pressure and core stability. Breathe steadily.
Letting the stability ball wobble or drop due to insufficient squeezing force from the limbs.

Pose.safety: Move with slow, controlled motions to maintain balance and engage the correct muscles. Keep your spine in a neutral, long position—avoid arching or rounding your back. Focus on stability over speed. If you have wrist or shoulder issues, ensure proper hand placement and avoid locking your elbows.
Pose.Name: Bird Dog

Focused_Muscles.Primary: Core (Transverse Abdominis, Multifidus - deep spinal muscles), Glutes (Maximus)
Focused_Muscles.Secondary: Shoulders (Deltoids), Lower Back (Erector Spinae as stabilizers)

Pose.Preferred: Ideal for morning routines to gently activate the core and posterior chain. Can be done on an empty stomach.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Lower Back Pain (non-specific), Poor Posture, Lack of Coordination and Balance
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds spinal stability, improves proprioception (body awareness), and helps prevent back injuries by strengthening supportive muscles.

steps.step: Start on your hands and knees in a tabletop position. Place your hands directly under your shoulders and your knees directly under your hips. Keep your spine in a neutral, flat position—neither arched nor sagging. Look down at the floor.

Inhale to prepare. Exhale as you gently engage your core. Simultaneously extend your right arm straight forward (in line with your shoulder) and your left leg straight back (in line with your hip). Keep your hips and shoulders square to the floor.
Hold the extended position for 1-2 seconds. Focus on maintaining perfect balance without tilting or rotating your torso. Your body should form a straight line from your fingertips to your heel.

Inhale as you slowly return your arm and leg to the starting tabletop position with control. Repeat on the opposite side, extending your left arm and right leg. That is one repetition. Aim for 10-12 repetitions per side for 2-3 sets.

**Do not lift your arm or leg higher than your back can stay level.** The goal is stability, not height. Imagine balancing a glass of water on your lower back. If you wobble, reduce your range of motion until you can perform the movement steadily.

Pose.safety: Move with slow, controlled motions to maintain balance and engage the correct muscles. Keep your spine in a neutral, long position—avoid arching or rounding your back. Focus on stability over speed. If you have wrist or shoulder issues, ensure proper hand placement and avoid locking your elbows.
Pose.Name: Bird Dog

Focused_Muscles.Primary: Core (Transverse Abdominis, Multifidus - deep spinal muscles), Glutes (Maximus)
Focused_Muscles.Secondary: Shoulders (Deltoids), Lower Back (Erector Spinae as stabilizers)

Pose.Preferred: Ideal for morning routines to gently activate the core and posterior chain. Can be done on an empty stomach.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Lower Back Pain (non-specific), Poor Posture, Lack of Coordination and Balance
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds spinal stability, improves proprioception (body awareness), and helps prevent back injuries by strengthening supportive muscles.

steps.step: Start on your hands and knees in a tabletop position. Place your hands directly under your shoulders and your knees directly under your hips. Keep your spine in a neutral, flat position—neither arched nor sagging. Look down at the floor.

Inhale to prepare. Exhale as you gently engage your core. Simultaneously extend your right arm straight forward (in line with your shoulder) and your left leg straight back (in line with your hip). Keep your hips and shoulders square to the floor.
Hold the extended position for 1-2 seconds. Focus on maintaining perfect balance without tilting or rotating your torso. Your body should form a straight line from your fingertips to your heel.

Inhale as you slowly return your arm and leg to the starting tabletop position with control. Repeat on the opposite side, extending your left arm and right leg. That is one repetition. Aim for 10-12 repetitions per side for 2-3 sets.

**Do not lift your arm or leg higher than your back can stay level.** The goal is stability, not height. Imagine balancing a glass of water on your lower back. If you wobble, reduce your range of motion until you can perform the movement steadily.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the hips to tilt or rotate when extending the arm and leg, compromising spinal alignment.
Arching the lower back or lifting the extended limb too high, which can strain the lumbar spine.
Looking up or turning the head, which can misalign the neck and disrupt balance.
Moving too quickly or using momentum instead of relying on muscle control for stability.

Pose.safety: Maintain a strong, engaged core to keep your balance on the ball. Avoid rounding your spine; keep your chest lifted and back straight. Move in a controlled manner—do not use momentum to swing. If you feel unstable, perform without weight or with your feet wider apart for a better base.
Pose.Name: Stability Ball Russian Twist
Pose.Equipment: Stability Ball (Swiss Ball), Optional: Dumbbell, Medicine Ball, or Weight Plate
Pose.Preferred: Can be done in the morning after a light warm-up. Provides both core activation and balance training to start the day.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Poor Rotational Stability, Weak Core Muscles, Lack of Balance and Coordination
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Enhances functional core strength for twisting movements, improves posture, and reduces risk of injury during sports or daily activities.

steps.step: Sit on the stability ball. Walk your feet forward as you lean back, rolling the ball until it supports your mid to upper back. Your knees should be bent at 90 degrees, feet flat on the floor hip-width apart. Lift your chest to create a straight torso from knees to shoulders. Clasp your hands together or hold a light weight at your chest.
Inhale to brace your core. Exhale as you slowly rotate your torso to one side, keeping your hips stable and the ball still. Lead the movement with your chest and shoulders, not just your arms.
Pause briefly when you feel a gentle stretch in your side abs. Inhale as you return to the center with control, maintaining your balance on the ball.
Exhale as you rotate to the opposite side. Continue alternating sides in a slow, rhythmic motion. Aim for 10-15 repetitions per side for 2-3 sets.

**Focus on keeping the ball completely still.** Any rocking or rolling means your core is not fully engaged to stabilize your spine. Start with no weight to master the balance, and only add resistance once you can perform the movement without wobbling.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the stability ball to rock or roll side-to-side, indicating insufficient core engagement and balance.
Dropping the chest or rounding the upper back, which shifts stress to the lower back and reduces oblique activation.
Using only the arms to swing the weight, rather than rotating the entire torso from the core muscles.
Moving too fast, which compromises form and reduces the effectiveness of the stability challenge.

Pose.safety: Ensure the stability ball is secure and does not slip. Keep the movement controlled to prevent straining your neck or lower back. Engage your core throughout—do not use momentum to rock back and forth. If you have balance issues, perform with feet on the floor before progressing to elevation.
Pose.Name: Stability Ball Feet Elevated Crunch
Pose.Equipment: Stability Ball (Swiss Ball), Optional: Exercise Mat

Focused_Muscles.Primary: Rectus Abdominis (Upper and Lower), Transverse Abdominis

Pose.Preferred: Suitable for morning core workouts after a brief warm-up. Provides activation and balance training to start the day.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Abdominal Muscles, Poor Core Stability and Balance, Sedentary Lifestyle
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Improves overall core endurance, enhances mind-muscle connection, and supports spinal health by building stabilizing strength.

steps.step: Lie on your back on the floor. Place your lower legs (calves/ankles) on top of a stability ball. Extend your arms overhead or place your hands lightly behind your head (avoid pulling your neck). Engage your core to press your lower back into the floor.

Inhale to prepare. As you exhale, gently squeeze the ball with your legs to stabilize it. Engage your abdominals, lifting your head, neck, and shoulder blades off the floor while simultaneously curling your torso upward.

At the top of the movement, focus on a strong contraction in your abdominal muscles. Keep the ball stable with your legs and avoid letting it roll. Your gaze should be toward the ceiling or slightly forward, not at your feet.
Inhale as you slowly lower back down to the starting position with control, maintaining core engagement and ball stability. Aim for 12-15 repetitions for 2-3 sets.

**Think of bringing your ribcage toward your pelvis**, not just lifting your shoulders. The leg elevation increases core demand by reducing stability—if the ball rolls, you’re likely using momentum. Start with small, controlled crunches and increase range of motion as you gain strength.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the legs to rock the body and create momentum instead of isolating the abdominal muscles.
Pulling the neck forward with the hands, which strains the cervical spine and takes focus away from the core.
Allowing the stability ball to roll or become unstable due to insufficient leg engagement and core control.
Arching the lower back off the floor on the descent, which reduces core engagement and can cause back strain.

Pose.safety: Maintain a firm grip on the stability rings to prevent slipping. Avoid swinging or using momentum to lift your legs—focus on controlled movement. Keep your shoulders engaged and down, away from your ears, to protect the shoulder joints. If you experience shoulder, wrist, or lower back discomfort, discontinue and consider a regression (e.g., lying leg raises).
Pose.Name: Stability Ring Hanging Knee Raise
Pose.Equipment: Stability/Gymnastics Rings, Pull-Up Bar or Rig to Hang Rings, Optional: Gloves for Grip

Focused_Muscles.Stabilizers: Latissimus Dorsi, Shoulders (Deltoids), Upper Back, Core (for anti-rotation)

Pose.Preferred: Can be done in the morning after a thorough warm-up of the shoulders, core, and grip. Not recommended on a completely empty stomach if full body engagement is needed.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Lower Abdominals, Poor Grip Strength, Lack of Upper Body and Core Coordination
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Enhances functional core strength for lifting and stability, improves shoulder stability, and builds foundational strength for advanced calisthenics movements.

steps.step: Adjust the stability rings to an appropriate height. Grip each ring firmly with an overhand grip. Hang with your arms fully extended, keeping your shoulders engaged (slightly depressed). Let your legs hang straight down, with your body in a straight line from shoulders to ankles.
Inhale to brace your core. Exhale as you slowly draw your knees upward toward your chest by contracting your lower abdominals. Keep the movement controlled and avoid swinging.

At the top of the movement, pause for a moment and focus on squeezing your abs. Your knees should be as high as possible without rounding your upper back excessively. Keep your gaze forward to maintain a neutral spine.
Inhale as you slowly lower your legs back to the starting hanging position with full control. Resist swinging. Aim for 8-12 repetitions for 2-3 sets.

**Start with a slight bend in the knees** if straight legs are too challenging. The key is to prevent any swinging—imagine moving in slow motion. If your grip gives out before your abs, use wrist straps or focus on grip-strength exercises separately.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using momentum to swing the legs up, which reduces core engagement and increases strain on the lower back and shoulders.
Shrugging the shoulders up toward the ears, which can lead to neck and shoulder tension.
Rounding the upper back excessively at the top of the movement, compromising spinal alignment.
Lowering the legs too quickly, which creates a swinging motion and loss of control for the next repetition.

Pose.safety: Ensure the parallettes are stable and on a non-slip surface. Maintain a strong, straight plank position throughout—avoid letting your hips sag or rise. Keep your shoulders engaged and directly above your hands. Move with control to prevent wrist or shoulder strain. If you have wrist issues, perform on flat ground first.
Pose.Name: Parallette Mountain Climber

Focused_Muscles.Primary: Core (Rectus Abdominis, Transverse Abdominis), Hip Flexors

Pose.Preferred: Excellent for morning cardio and core activation. Elevates heart rate while building shoulder stability. Perform after a brief warm-up.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Poor Cardiovascular Endurance, Weak Core Stability, Limited Shoulder Mobility, Sedentary Lifestyle
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Enhances coordination and agility, improves functional pushing strength, and builds resilience in the shoulder girdle.

steps.step: Place two parallettes on the floor shoulder-width apart. Grip the handles firmly with your hands directly under your shoulders. Step back into a plank position with your body forming a straight line from head to heels. Engage your core and glutes.

Inhale to brace. Exhale as you drive your right knee forcefully toward your chest, keeping your hips level and your torso stable. Aim to bring your knee as close to your chest or elbow as possible without rounding your upper back.
Quickly and with control, return your right foot to the starting position while simultaneously driving your left knee toward your chest. This creates a continuous, rhythmic "climbing" motion.
Continue alternating knees in a steady, controlled rhythm. Aim for 30-60 seconds of continuous movement, or 20-30 total reps (10-15 per side) for 2-3 sets.

**The parallettes allow for a deeper range of motion**—take advantage of this by pressing firmly through the handles and keeping your shoulders active (not sagging into your joints). To prevent hip bouncing, imagine a laser beam on your lower back; it should stay perfectly still.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the hips to bounce, sag, or rise with each knee drive, which reduces core engagement and strains the lower back.
Shifting body weight unevenly between the parallettes, causing shoulder instability and wobbling of the equipment.
Rushing the movement without control, leading to sloppy form and reduced muscular engagement.
Letting the shoulders creep up toward the ears or allowing the chest to cave inward.

Pose.safety: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement—avoid arching or rounding your back. Keep your hips square and level. Move slowly and with control to prevent losing balance. If you feel strain in your lower back, reduce the hover height or return to the basic Bird Dog progression.
Pose.Name: Bodyweight Knee Hover Bird Dog

Focused_Muscles.Stabilizers: Lower Back (Erector Spinae), Hip Abductors, Scapular Stabilizers

Pose.Preferred: Ideal for morning core activation and balance training. Gently wakes up the posterior chain and deep stabilizers.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Lower Back Pain (due to core weakness), Poor Postural Control, Imbalance Between Left and Right Sides
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds foundational core stability, improves hip and shoulder coordination, and enhances proprioception for daily movements.

steps.step: Start on your hands and knees in a tabletop position. Place your hands directly under your shoulders and your knees directly under your hips. Keep your spine in a neutral, flat position. Engage your core gently.

Inhale to prepare. Exhale as you engage your quadriceps and core to lift both knees approximately 1-2 inches off the floor, hovering. Maintain a flat back and keep your weight evenly distributed between your hands and toes. Hold this hover position stable.

Maintaining the knee hover, slowly extend your right arm forward and your left leg backward simultaneously. Keep your hips square and level. Your body should form a straight line from your fingertips to your heel. Hold briefly.

With control, return your arm and leg to the starting hover position. Repeat on the opposite side (left arm, right leg). That is one repetition. Aim for 6-10 repetitions per side for 2-3 sets. Lower knees to rest between sets.

**This is an advanced stability variation.** The key challenge is keeping your knees hovering throughout the entire set—do not let them touch the floor between repetitions. If you cannot maintain a flat back or stable hips, master the standard Bird Dog first before attempting the hover.

Pose.common_mistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch or sag while hovering the knees, which strains the lumbar spine. Dropping the knees to the floor between repetitions instead of maintaining a continuous hover. Rotating the hips or shoulders when extending the arm and leg, compromising spinal alignment. Shifting weight unevenly onto one hand or foot, causing instability and wobbling. </common_mistakes

Pose.safety: Maintain constant core engagement throughout the movement to protect your lower back. Avoid using momentum to swing the ball—move with control. Keep your movements slow and deliberate, especially when passing the ball. If you feel lower back strain, reduce your range of motion or perform the exercise with bent knees.
Pose.Name: Stability Ball V-Up Pass

Focused_Muscles.Primary: Rectus Abdominis (Upper and Lower), Transverse Abdominis

Pose.Preferred: Challenging morning core exercise. Best performed after a thorough warm-up to activate the entire core complex.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Upper and Lower Abdominal Imbalance, Poor Coordination, Limited Hip Flexibility
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Develops integrated core strength, improves mind-muscle connection between upper and lower body, and enhances functional movement patterns.

steps.step: Lie flat on your back on a mat. Hold a stability ball with both hands extended overhead, arms straight. Extend your legs straight out along the floor. Engage your core by pressing your lower back into the mat.

Inhale to prepare. Exhale as you simultaneously lift your upper body and legs off the floor, reaching your arms and legs toward the ceiling. Your body should form a "V" shape. Keep your arms straight as you bring the ball toward your feet.
At the top of the V-up, carefully pass the ball from your hands to your legs, clamping it between your ankles or lower shins. Squeeze the ball firmly with your legs to secure it.

Inhale as you slowly lower both your upper body and legs back to the starting position with control, keeping the ball secured between your legs. On your next repetition, lift up and pass the ball back from your legs to your hands. Continue alternating passes. Aim for 8-12 repetitions for 2-3 sets.

**Control the descent—it's just as important as the lift.** Lowering slowly is where your core works hardest. If the full V-up is too challenging, keep your knees bent at 90 degrees (tabletop position) to shorten the lever arm and reduce difficulty.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using momentum to swing the legs and arms up instead of relying on a controlled abdominal contraction.
Dropping the ball or losing control during the hand-to-leg or leg-to-hand pass.
Allowing the lower back to arch off the mat during the descent, which strains the lumbar spine.
Rushing through the movement, especially the pass, leading to sloppy form and reduced core engagement.

Pose.safety: Keep your lower back pressed firmly into the floor throughout the entire movement. Move slowly and with control—do not use momentum. Only extend your limbs as far as you can while maintaining a neutral spine and stable core. If you feel lower back arching, reduce your range of motion.
Pose.Name: Bodyweight Dead Bug

Focused_Muscles.Stabilizers: Lower Back (Erector Spinae - in neutral position), Shoulders, Quadriceps

Pose.Preferred: Excellent low-impact morning exercise to activate the deep core stabilizers and improve mind-muscle connection.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Lower Back Pain (due to core instability), Poor Core Coordination, Weak Deep Abdominal Muscles
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds foundational core stability, improves spinal protection mechanisms, and enhances coordination between limbs and torso.

steps.step: Lie flat on your back on a mat. Lift your legs to a tabletop position with your knees bent at 90 degrees directly over your hips. Raise your arms straight up toward the ceiling with your hands directly over your shoulders. Press your lower back firmly into the mat.

Inhale to brace your core. Exhale as you slowly extend your right arm overhead and your left leg toward the floor simultaneously. Keep both moving limbs hovering just above the mat—do not let them rest. Maintain the press of your lower back into the floor.
Inhale as you slowly return your extended arm and leg back to the starting tabletop position with control, maintaining core engagement throughout.
Exhale as you extend your left arm and right leg. Continue alternating sides in a slow, controlled, rhythmic motion. Aim for 8-12 repetitions per side for 2-3 sets.

**Imagine you are lying on a very fragile surface that will crack if your lower back lifts off.** This mental cue helps maintain spinal contact. Move as slowly as you need to—the Dead Bug is about control, not speed. If you feel your back arching, reduce your range of motion immediately.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the lower back to arch off the mat, which shifts the work away from the deep core and strains the lumbar spine.
Moving too quickly and using momentum instead of controlled, muscle-driven movement.
Letting the extended limb rest on the floor instead of hovering, reducing time under tension.
Holding the breath; remember to exhale during the extension phase for better core activation.

Pose.safety: Keep your lower back pressed firmly into the floor throughout the movement. Avoid pulling on your neck with your hands—your head should rest lightly in your fingertips. Engage your core to lift your shoulder blades, not your neck. If you feel neck strain, reduce the range of motion or perform with hands across your chest.
Pose.Name: Bodyweight Alternating Heel Taps
Pose.Preferred: Gentle morning core activation exercise. Ideal for waking up the abdominals without excessive spinal loading.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Upper Abdominals, Poor Oblique Engagement, Sedentary Core Weakness
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Improves rotational core control, enhances posture, and builds foundational strength for more advanced core exercises.

steps.step: Lie flat on your back on a mat. Bend your knees and place your feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart, about 12-16 inches from your glutes. Lightly place your fingertips behind your head, elbows wide. Press your lower back into the mat.

Inhale to prepare. Exhale as you engage your core and gently curl your head, neck, and shoulder blades off the floor. Keep your lower back pressed down. Hold this lifted position throughout the entire set.

Maintaining the lifted crunch position, slowly reach your right fingertips toward your right heel. Tap your heel lightly, then return your hand to the starting position behind your head. Keep your torso stable—do not rotate excessively.
Reach your left fingertips toward your left heel. Continue alternating sides in a slow, controlled manner. Aim for 12-16 repetitions (each side counts as one rep) for 2-3 sets.

**Do not let your shoulder blades touch the floor between taps.** Keeping your upper back lifted throughout the entire set maintains constant tension on your abdominals. Focus on a slight twist from your rib cage, not just reaching your arm. If your neck hurts, imagine holding an orange under your chin to maintain proper alignment.

common_mistakes.mistake: Pulling the head and neck forward with the hands, causing cervical strain instead of core engagement.
Lowering the shoulder blades to the floor between each tap, releasing tension from the abdominals.
Rotating the entire torso excessively rather than initiating the movement from the oblique muscles.
Allowing the lower back to arch off the mat, which reduces core activation and strains the spine.

Pose.safety: Maintain a straight line from your head to your knees—avoid sagging your hips or arching your back. Keep your neck in a neutral position by looking down at the floor. Engage your core and glutes throughout the hold. If you feel lower back strain, check your hip position and tighten your abdominals.
Pose.Name: Bodyweight Kneeling Forearm Plank

Focused_Muscles.Stabilizers: Lower Back (Erector Spinae), Chest (Pectorals), Neck Flexors

Pose.Preferred: Perfect beginner morning exercise to activate the core and build foundational stability. Gentle on the lower back and wrists.

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Core Muscles, Poor Postural Endurance, Lower Back Tenderness
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds core stamina, improves spinal alignment awareness, and serves as a safe entry point for more advanced plank variations.

steps.step: Begin on your hands and knees. Lower yourself onto your forearms, placing your elbows directly under your shoulders. Your forearms should be parallel to each other, palms flat on the mat or hands clasped. Extend your legs behind you and rest your knees on the floor.

Inhale to prepare. Exhale as you engage your core by drawing your belly button toward your spine. Squeeze your glutes gently. Lift your hips slightly so your body forms a straight, diagonal line from your head to your knees.
Hold this position, maintaining a flat back and neutral neck. Your gaze should be toward the floor, just beyond your hands. Breathe steadily throughout the hold. Do not let your hips sag or rise.
Hold for 20-45 seconds as a beginner. Rest for 30 seconds. Repeat for 3-4 sets. Focus on maintaining perfect form throughout the entire hold—quality over duration.

**Imagine your body is a sturdy tabletop.** Your back should be completely flat—neither arched nor rounded. If you feel pressure in your lower back, tighten your abs and glutes more. This modified version is ideal for building confidence and strength before progressing to a full plank on your toes.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the hips to sag toward the floor, which strains the lower back and reduces core engagement.
Lifting the hips too high, turning the exercise into a pike position and shifting focus away from the core.
Looking up or tucking the chin excessively, misaligning the cervical spine.
Holding the breath or breathing shallowly; maintain steady, rhythmic breathing throughout the hold.

Pose.safety: Maintain a neutral spine and keep your hips stable throughout the circular motion. Initiate the movement from your core, not your legs. Keep your chest lifted and avoid rounding your back.
Pose.Name: Bodyweight Seated Ab Circles

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Core Endurance, Poor Hip Stability
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Improves rotational core control and abdominal stamina

steps.step: Sit on the mat with your knees bent and feet flat. Lean back slightly to a 45-degree angle, keeping your spine straight. Place your hands on the floor beside your hips for support.
Lift both feet a few inches off the floor, balancing on your sit bones. Keep your knees bent at 90 degrees.
Using your core, move both knees together in a slow, controlled circular motion—clockwise 5-10 times, then counterclockwise.
Complete 3-5 circles in each direction per set. Aim for 2-3 sets.
Make the circles as wide as possible while keeping your torso completely still. Only your legs should move.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rocking the torso side to side instead of isolating leg movement.
Rounding the lower back, reducing core engagement.
Rushing the circles instead of controlling the motion.
Holding the breath throughout the movement.

Pose.safety: Maintain a firm grip on the rings and avoid swinging. Keep your shoulders engaged and depressed. Control the oblique movement without rotating the torso excessively.
Pose.Name: Ring Hanging Oblique Knee Raise
Pose.Equipment: Stability Rings, Pull-Up Bar or Rig

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Obliques, Poor Rotational Core Strength
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds lateral core stability and grip endurance

steps.step: Hang from rings with arms fully extended, shoulders engaged. Legs hang straight down.
Engage your core. Keeping legs together, lift your knees diagonally toward your right elbow.
Pause briefly at the top, squeezing your right oblique. Avoid twisting your shoulders.
Lower with control and repeat on the left side. Alternate sides for 8-12 reps per side, 2-3 sets.
Focus on lifting with your oblique, not swinging your legs. Start with bent knees before progressing to straight legs.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using momentum to swing the legs upward.
Rotating the shoulders toward the lifting side.
Letting the shoulders shrug up toward the ears.
Lowering legs too quickly, creating a swinging motion.

Pose.safety: Keep your body in a rigid straight line from head to heels. Do not let your hips sag. Move the ball in small, controlled circles—larger circles increase difficulty significantly.
Pose.Name: Stability Ball Stir the Pot

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Deep Core Instability, Weak Shoulder Stabilizers
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds anti-rotational core strength and shoulder endurance

steps.step: Place forearms on a stability ball in a plank position. Elbows under shoulders, body in a straight line from head to heels.
Brace your core and glutes. Keep hips completely still and level.
Move your forearms in slow, controlled clockwise circles, "stirring" the ball. Keep your body rigid.
Perform 5-10 circles clockwise, then 5-10 counterclockwise. Repeat for 2-3 sets.
The smaller the circle, the easier the exercise. Start with tiny circles and gradually increase diameter as you gain stability.

common_mistakes.mistake: Letting the hips sag or swing opposite to the arm movement.
Moving the ball too fast without control.
Allowing the lower back to arch.
Holding the breath during circular motion.

Pose.safety: Maintain a strong plank position throughout. Keep your hips level and avoid excessive rotation. Move with control to prevent shoulder strain.
Pose.Name: Bodyweight Alternating Lateral Kick Through

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Poor Rotational Stability, Weak Anti-Rotation Core
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Enhances dynamic core control and shoulder stability

steps.step: Start in a high plank position, hands under shoulders, body straight.
Lift your right hand and rotate your torso, kicking your right leg through laterally toward the left side.
Return to plank and repeat on the opposite side.
Alternate sides for 10-16 total reps (5-8 per side) for 2-3 sets.
Keep your hips as low and stable as possible. The movement should come from rotation, not hip lifting.

common_mistakes.mistake: Lifting the hips too high during the kick through.
Letting the supporting shoulder collapse.
Rushing the movement without control.
Failing to fully extend the leg during the kick.

Pose.safety: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the rotation. Avoid rounding your back. Choose a light ball to start and focus on controlled rotation, not speed.
Pose.Name: Slam Ball Russian Twist
Pose.Equipment: Slam Ball or Medicine Ball, Exercise Mat

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Rotational Core, Poor Oblique Strength
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds functional twisting strength and spinal stability

steps.step: Sit on the mat, knees bent, feet elevated or crossed. Hold a slam ball at your chest.
Lean back to a 45-degree angle, keeping your spine straight.
Rotate your torso to the right, tapping the ball beside your hip, then to the left.
Continue alternating sides for 12-16 reps (6-8 per side) for 2-3 sets.
Keep your chest lifted and avoid rounding forward. Rotate from your torso, not your arms.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rounding the lower back and dropping the chest.
Using only arms to move the ball without torso rotation.
Letting feet touch the floor (if elevated).
Moving too fast with momentum.

Pose.safety: Maintain constant tension in your core and crush grip throughout the movement. Keep your lower back pressed into the floor. Move slowly and with control.
Pose.Name: Dumbbell Crush Grip Otis Up

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Upper/Lower Abdominal Imbalance, Weak Grip Strength
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds integrated core control and crushing grip endurance

steps.step: Lie on your back, legs extended. Hold a dumbbell vertically against your chest with both hands, squeezing the head.
Engage your core. Slowly curl your upper body off the floor, keeping the weight pressed against your chest.
At the top, squeeze the dumbbell head firmly and pause. Lower back down with control.
Perform 10-15 controlled repetitions for 2-3 sets.
The "crush grip" activates your forearms and increases core tension. Squeeze the dumbbell as hard as you can throughout the movement.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using momentum to jerk the upper body up.
Releasing grip tension during the movement.
Arching the lower back off the floor.
Pulling with the neck instead of engaging the core.

Pose.safety: Keep your body in a rigid straight line throughout the movement. Avoid letting your hips sag or rotate. Move slowly and with control to maintain stability.
Pose.Name: Single Arm Dumbbell Side Plank Reach Through
Pose.Preferred_Time: Core Strength or Upper Body Day

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Lateral Core, Poor Shoulder Stability
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds anti-rotational strength and hip stability

steps.step: Begin in a side plank on your right forearm, body straight. Hold a dumbbell in your left hand extended upward.
Slowly reach the dumbbell underneath your torso toward your right side, rotating your upper body.
Return to the starting position with control, keeping hips elevated.
Perform 8-12 reps, then switch sides. Complete 2-3 sets per side.
Don't let your hips drop during the reach-through. The movement should be challenging for your obliques, not your shoulder.

common_mistakes.mistake: Letting the hips sag toward the floor.
Rushing the reach-through without control.
Twisting the hips instead of keeping them stacked.
Using a weight that's too heavy, compromising form.

Pose.safety: Maintain a neutral spine—do not arch or round your back. Engage your core before initiating the roll. Only roll out as far as you can while maintaining a straight back.
Pose.Name: Ab Wheel Kneeling Rollout

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Anti-Extension Core Strength, Poor Spinal Stability
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds resilience against lower back arching and improves posture

steps.step: Kneel on the mat, hold the ab wheel under your shoulders, arms extended.
Engage your core and glutes. Maintain a neutral spine.
Slowly roll the wheel forward, extending your body while keeping your back flat.
Pull the wheel back to start using your core, not your arms.
Your lower back should never arch. Stop rolling forward the moment you feel your back begin to sag.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the lower back to arch or sag during the rollout.
Rolling out too far without sufficient core strength.
Using arm strength to pull back instead of the core.
Hip flexion instead of maintaining a straight body line.

Pose.safety: Maintain a neutral spine and avoid using momentum. Keep your hips stable throughout the movement. Control the weight on both the crunch and the return.
Pose.Name: Cable Seated Crunch

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Upper Abdominal Weakness, Poor Core Isolation
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds concentrated abdominal contraction strength

steps.step: Sit on a bench facing a cable machine. Grip the rope attachment behind your head, elbows wide.
Exhale and curl your upper body downward, bringing your elbows toward your thighs.
Pause briefly at the bottom, squeezing your abs. Keep hips stationary.
Inhale and return to start with control. Perform 12-15 reps for 3 sets.
Imagine you're trying to roll your rib cage toward your pelvis. Don't just move your arms—curl your entire torso.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using arm strength to pull the cable instead of curling the torso.
Rocking the hips forward and backward.
Rounding the shoulders without engaging the abs.
Using momentum to swing the weight.

Pose.safety: Keep your hips stable and avoid rocking backward. Control the movement throughout—do not let the weight pull you back.
Pose.Name: Cable Kneeling Crunch
Pose.Equipment: Cable Machine, Rope Attachment, Knee Pad

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Core Weakness, Poor Abdominal Contraction Control
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds concentrated spinal flexion strength

steps.step: Kneel facing a cable machine, holding the rope attachment behind your head.
Exhale and curl your upper body downward, bringing elbows toward thighs.
Pause at the bottom, squeezing your abs. Keep hips extended, not sitting back.
Inhale and return with control. Perform 12-15 reps for 3 sets.
Keep your hips pushed forward throughout the movement. This maintains constant tension on your abs.

common_mistakes.mistake: Sitting back onto the heels, reducing core engagement.
Using arm strength instead of curling the torso.
Allowing the lower back to hyperextend.
Letting the weight pull you back too quickly.

Pose.safety: Maintain control throughout the pass. Avoid arching your lower back. Only go as low as you can while keeping your legs straight and back flat.
Pose.Name: Medicine Ball V Up

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Upper/Lower Abdominal Imbalance, Poor Coordination
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds integrated core strength and limb coordination

steps.step: Lie on your back, arms extended overhead holding a medicine ball, legs straight.
Simultaneously lift your arms and legs to meet over your torso, passing the ball to your feet.
Secure the ball between your ankles/lower shins. Lower with control.
On the next rep, pass the ball back from feet to hands. Alternate passes. Aim for 8-12 reps, 2-3 sets.
Keep your legs as straight as possible. If you can't straighten them fully, bend your knees slightly and work on flexibility.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using momentum to swing the limbs up.
Arching the lower back off the floor.
Dropping the ball during the pass.
Rushing the movement without control.

Pose.safety: Maintain a rigid plank position throughout. Keep your hips level and avoid sagging. Control the movement on both the tuck and the extension.
Pose.Name: Suspension Knee Tuck

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Core Stability, Poor Body Tension Control
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds integrated core strength and shoulder stability

steps.step: Place feet in suspension straps, assume a plank position on your hands.
Engage your core and draw both knees toward your chest.
Pause briefly at the top, then slowly extend legs back to plank.
Perform 10-15 reps for 2-3 sets.
Don't let your hips sag or rise. Keep your back flat like a tabletop throughout the movement.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the hips to sag or pike up.
Using momentum to swing the knees in.
Letting the lower back arch during extension.
Rushing the movement without control.

Pose.safety: Maintain a stable plank position. Avoid rotating your hips—only your legs should move laterally. Control the movement throughout.
Pose.Name: Suspension Lateral Knee Tuck

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Weak Obliques, Poor Rotational Stability
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds lateral core control and shoulder stability

steps.step: Place feet in suspension straps, assume a plank position on your hands.
Draw both knees toward your left elbow, keeping hips square.
Extend back to plank, then tuck toward your right elbow.
Alternate sides for 10-16 total reps (5-8 per side) for 2-3 sets.
Keep your shoulders and hips as stable as possible. The movement comes from your obliques, not from twisting your torso.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rotating the hips and shoulders toward the tucking side.
Letting the hips sag during the movement.
Using momentum to swing the legs laterally.
Lifting the hips too high.

Pose.safety: This is a complex, full-body movement. Start with light weight or no weight to master the pattern. Keep the dumbbell stable and vertical at all times. Move slowly and deliberately.
Pose.Name: Single Arm Dumbbell Turkish Get Up
Pose.Equipment: Single Dumbbell or Kettlebell, Exercise Mat

Focused_Muscles.Stabilizers: Every major muscle group—full body integration

Pose.Preferred_Time: Strength or Mobility Day, After Warm-Up

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Poor Full-Body Coordination, Weak Overhead Stability, Limited Hip Mobility
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds integrated strength, shoulder stability, and functional movement patterns

steps.step: Lie on your back, hold a dumbbell in your right hand pressed straight up. Bend your right knee, foot flat. Left leg straight, left arm at 45 degrees.
Roll to your left elbow, keeping the weight pressed overhead and vertical.
Press onto your left hand, lifting your torso. Keep weight overhead.
Lift your hips, sweep your left leg under you into a half-kneeling position. Weight remains overhead.
Stand up, keeping weight overhead. Reverse the sequence to return. Perform 3-5 reps per side.

common_mistakes.mistake: Letting the dumbbell tilt or wobble overhead.
Taking eyes off the weight during transitions.
Rushing through the sequence without control.
Using too much weight before mastering form.

Pose.safety: Maintain a flat back throughout the crawl. Keep your hips low and stable. Move with control—do not rush.
Pose.Name: Bodyweight Bear Crawl

Diseases_Cured.Targeted: Poor Core Stability, Lack of Coordination, Sedentary Lifestyle
Diseases_Cured.Preventive: Builds functional locomotion strength and cardiovascular endurance

steps.step: Start on hands and knees, lift knees 1-2 inches off floor, hovering. Back flat, hips level.
Move your right hand and left foot forward simultaneously, then left hand and right foot.
Keep hips low and stable throughout. Do not let knees drag or hips rise.
Crawl forward for 10-20 yards, then backward. Repeat for 3-5 sets.
Imagine you're crawling under a low ceiling—your hips cannot rise. Keep your core braced and back flat.

common_mistakes.mistake: Letting the knees drag on the floor.
Lifting the hips too high (downward dog position).
Rushing the crawl without coordinated movement.
Allowing the lower back to sag.
